title.rendered: Cancer survivors share their stories in podcast series

content.rendered:
Patients

Cancer survivors share their stories in podcast series

Listen as patients and advocates, including longtime cancer research advocate, Katie Couric, explore the triumphs and challenges that many cancer survivors face

November 30, 2020

Share this article

Thankfully, there are millions of cancer survivors in the U.S. today. And while survivors often experience victories, some may also face difficult physical and emotional obstacles. As part of Your Cancer Story, we collaborated with seven cancer patients and caregivers, including media personality Katie Couric, on an original new podcast series dedicated to sharing the real, unvarnished stories of cancer survivors as they navigate their individually defined new “normal.”

In the first episode, listen as Dylan and JB recount the internal struggles following their cancer diagnoses, as well as the personal transformations they both experienced.

Find all four episodes at YourCancerStory.com, or subscribe to the podcast on iTunes or Spotify.

If you are a survivor or a caregiver, we hope that you find some solace in these stories. Remember, you are not alone.

Listen now

“I think that this has definitely forced me to live in the now. You just don’t know how much longer you’re going to have it.”

  • Seyna, breast cancer survivor

“I want people to know that you’re not alone and that for all you’re going through, there is a light at the end of the tunnel.”

  • Kristi, caregiver

“I decided that it was really important for me to inform people, that I needed to help them protect their own health and the health of their loved ones by getting screened.”

– Katie Couric, caregiver and cancer research advocate

Want to learn more?

This four-part podcast series is part of Your Cancer Story, a go-to online hub for patients, caregivers and survivors dealing with cancer.

Visit Your Cancer Story
Discover more stories

Key takeaways from this year’s U.N. General Assembly

This leader is dedicated to developing future women leaders

Debunking type 2 diabetes misconceptions

View all stories

related_content_item_one.post_content:
Our focus     |     Discovery efforts     |     Community support     |     Stories

Cell-based therapies and T/NK cell engagers

Cell-based therapies and T/NK cell engagers

Utilizing allogeneic T and NK cells and T/NK cell engagers that aim to attack tumors.

Immune agonists

Immune agonists

Molecules designed to stimulate immune system functions, such as enhancing the activity of anti-tumor immune cells.

Inhibition of negative immune regulators

Inhibition of negative immune regulators

Designed to block the action of molecules that suppress the immune system to potentially enable a more robust anti-tumor response.

Personalized cancer vaccines

Personalized cancer vaccines

Therapeutic vaccines based on patients’ specific cancer that could potentially prime the immune system to recognize certain characteristics and attack the cancer cells.

Tumor microenvironment modulators

Tumor microenvironment modulators

Seek to regulate the environment around tumors to influence how tumors grow and interact with the immune system.

https://www.merck.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2022/07/research-platform-1.jpghttps://www.merck.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2022/07/research-platform-1.jpg

related_content_item_two.post_content:
Four years after her stage 3 melanoma diagnosis, Bethany G. shows no signs of disease and is proud to be a cancer survivor. “Being done and knowing that you're finished is the most satisfying thing,” says Bethany, mother of two young girls. “It's like this prize that you win for going through all of this.”

Today, Bethany joins the millions of people in the U.S. who are cancer survivors. This growing number of cancer survivors is due in large part to advancements in detection and treatments that have helped to shift many types of cancers from acute to chronic diseases.

But while cancer survivorship is a celebrated victory, it is also often met with a host of complicated challenges. Once cancer treatment is over, many survivors, including Bethany, may be wondering about what comes next. And beyond the very real fears of reoccurrence, survivors face a host of challenges that are hard to anticipate or plan for, from emotional and mental strain to new physical limitations.

“A lot of cancer patients search for their new ‘normal’ after treatment,” explains Bethany as she talks candidly about her identity as a survivor in a new video presented by Your Cancer Story – an online platform that provides information and support to people throughout every stage of the cancer journey, including survivorship. The website’s resources include tips on how to get important information about cancer care, ways to better communicate with loved ones and healthcare teams, strategies to cope with the emotional challenges of cancer, and inspiring stories from people who have been there before.

Learn more by visiting YourCancerStory.com and find support to help you feel your best, inside and out.
